statement:
Let $B$ be a betweenness relation on a set $A$.

If $(a,b,c)\in B$ and $(a,c,d)\in B$, then $(a,b,d)\in B$.

For each pair of elements $p,q\in A$, we can define five sets:

1.  $B_{*pq}:=\lbrace r\in A\mid (r,p,q)\in B\rbrace$,

2.  $B_{p*q}:=\lbrace r\in A\mid (p,r,q)\in B\rbrace$,

3.  $B_{pq*}:=\lbrace r\in A\mid (p,q,r)\in B\rbrace$,

4.  $B_{pq}:=B_{p*q}\cup\lbrace q\rbrace\cup B_{pq*}$, and

5.  $B(p,q):=B_{*pq}\cup\lbrace p\rbrace\cup B_{pq}$.

Then

-   $B_{*pq}=B_{qp*}.$

-   $B_{p*q}=B_{q*p}.$

-   The intersection of any pair of the first three sets contains at
    most one element, either $p$ or $q$.

-   Each of the sets can be partially ordered.

-   The partial order on $B_{pq}$ and $B(p,q)$ extends that of the
    subsets.
names: some theorems on the axioms of order
